Comments_Ratings: This has been a frustrating post.  Very few of the officers can actually use Burmese well enough to run meetings or even to understand normal conversation-- this includes those with 3/3 ratings.  almost all interaction is through english, or through LES.  although I only achieved a 2+/1+ rating, my spoken burmese is among the best in the embassy.  in fact i probably couldn't get the same rating today, though i could probably get a 3 in comprehension.  i am a strong language student but find that the infrastructure around burmese does not allow for easy learning.  the dictionaries are TERRIBLE.  the script is complicated, and when you hear a word there is no way to figure out how it is spelled.  so you simply cannot learn burmese by ear-plus-dictionary.  this is not a problem of the teachers, who try very hard.  it's a problem that there are three consonants that sound like "d"; another three that sound like "g"; another three vowels that sound like "a"; so when you hear "Gada", the possible permutations of the word are infinite and unless someone writes it for you, you can't look it up.  so it is a very hard language to learn.  (for comparison, i am a 3/3 in japanese and chinese and am a very comfortable speaker in those languages.
Translation_aids: checking english to burmese words only.  for the reasons above, burmese is impossible to spell into english unless you already know the word.

It takes more than a 3/3 level to have as much success as I did handling multi-lateral complex issues.  So my point is that after taking twice the Spanish test with your contractors (who quite honestly don't tend to speak the Castillian or Spanish I am used to but instead Venezuelan or South American --not my region) the grades I have been give by the proctors are pathetic.  When I asked, how would someone like me, who learned English as a second language, would ever get a 4/4 in the native language/Spanish? I speak classical Spanish. Pathetic.How is it possible then with a 3/3 that I am able to proofread, communicate clearly, review, edit, draft, everything in Spanish on a daily basis with everyone in the country I am currently living in--without any help of anyone?  How is it possible that I communicate with the Office of the President in this country without any assistance and our goals are met at the end of the day?  Yet, I speak and read at a 3/3 level?  Furthermore, how is it possible that I have to assist every day my colleague or everyone in this Embassy who did a "refresh" or went to FSI but they all ask me to handle all Spanish-speaking issues for the office?  My incoming colleague will take a "refresh" hence I can see myself handling many of her duties, because she doesn't speak it BUT ALSO will receive a 3/3 (just because she DID go to FSI and extended the contractor's time at FSI????)  Why the burden goes to the "native speaker" but not to the recently-FSI-graduated student who doesn't understand, speaks, reads it at my real level???? Pathetic.  So according to my last FSI proctor, in order for me to get to the 4/4 level or a 5/5 level, I must return to FSI, waste tax-payers money for three to five months or who knows, so that this "native Spanish speaker" get her 4/4 in the language she has been utilizing and speaking and proofreading her whole life. Add_tasks: I interview people for visas and citizenship services on a daily basis for hours every day and never learned Consular language in FSI training. I think it is essential that language training include Consular-specific training for entry-level officers who will spend most of their time interviewing in the language. We need to be able to understand a range of accents, know about professions and cultural references, and be familiar with geography, society, educational, and economic class markers. We interview children, adults, elderly, low-income and high-income, rural and urban individuals. Knowing how to talk about nuclear policies doesn't help, but knowing the difference between cattle and cows or between types of medical professions, or extended relatives - these types of societal vocabulary are much more important to our daily work. We also need to be able to quickly translate what we hear into written English case notes, and we need to know how to ask questions about people's lives, plans, and experiences. I think FSI was too focused on abstract language and sophisticated grammar, which do not prepare Consular officers well for the practical task of interviewing the average host country citizen.
